did.abstract: Edward Carpenter was a British socialist writer and poet, known for his advocacy of natural living, and for his writings on homosexuality and his open espousal of this identity. The collection contains letters and postcards, and printed ephemera.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Unknown. Separated from the Tamiment Library Manuscript Files Collection, 2004.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Edward Carpenter (1844-1929) was a British socialist writer and poet, known for his advocacy of natural living, and for his writings on homosexuality and his open espousal of this identity. Carpenter was born to a middle-class family, attended Cambridge University, worked for the University Extension movement in northern England, traveled and lectured, and in 1883 settled in Millthorpe, near Sheffield. In 1891, after his return from a trip to India to study Indian philosophy and religion, he met George Merrill, who would be his companion for nearly forty years. Among his works are Towards Democracy(1883) and The Intermediate Sex(1908). Crane also composed the socialist anthem England Arise!

list.item: Adapted from Philip Taylor’s "Biographical Note," at the Edward Carpenter Archive website. http://edwardcarpenter.net/index.htm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Contains three letters to, and one letter from Bertram Lloyd (aka "Wolfie"); one letter and two postcards to Harold Munro of the Poetry Bookshop, London; three letters and nine postcards to Grant Richards of London, pertaining to Carpenter’s desire to have Richards publish his The Story of Eros and Psycheand his Iolaus: an Anthology of Friendship; nine letters to Miss Annie Riley, first of Sheffield, later of Jamaica Plain, Massachusetts; a clipping from the Evening Standard noting Carpenter’s 80th birthday, and a brochure from the Edward Carpenter International Memorial Trust. All the letters and postcards are signed.

did.unittitle:
Lloyd, Bertram [aka E. Bertram, aka "Wolfie"]: Letters (to, from)
Contents:
- 1. B.L. [ALS] to E.C., undated, in German, on both sides of a sheet measuring 2.75" x 7.125"
- 2. E.C to E.B.L., postcard, 26 Jan 1920, [ALS]
- 3. E.C.[?] to "My Dear Wolfie" 2 Jan 1921, [ALS]
- 4. E.C. to "Dear Wolfie," 1 Dec 1923 [copy by Lloyd]
Munro, Harold [The Poetry Bookshop, 35 Devonshire St., London]: Letter and Two Postcards to [ALS]

Printed Ephemera [2 items]
Contents: "Scholar Recluse 80 To-Day" Evening Standard 29 Aug 1924; Edward Carpenter International Memorial Appeal [brochure, 1932]

Richards, Grant, 1872-1948 [9 Henrietta St., London], Three Letters and Nine Postcards to [all signed].
Contents: eleven of these [2 ltrs, 9 postcards] pertain to EC’s desire to have GR publish his The Story of Eros and Psyche; the 12th item [ltr, May 10, 1901] pertains to EC’s desire to have GR publish his Iolaus: an Anthology of Friendship

Riley, Annie, Miss: Nine Letters to [ALS]
Contents: three are addressed to AR in Sheffield, England, six to AR in Massachusetts (Townsend Centre, Jamaica Plain); the last letter is addressed to Nurse A.P. Riley
